data.title: make texture parameter of ImmediateGeometry.begin() optional ?
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.0.4.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

Sometimes, it could be handy if the texture parameter of `ImmediateGeometry.begin(primitive,texture)` was optional.

( and also, optionally, it would be handy if all the `PRIMITIVE_xxxx` constants were also bound to `ImmediateGeometry` too, so we don't have to look for them into `Mesh.PRIMITIVE_xxxx` )

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Fix SConstruct output file name
data.body: When I wanted to build Godot for iOS, output file names for 32 and 64 bits were the same

data.title: Unusual FileSystem behavior when creating new assets in folders
data.body:
Window 10 64-bit, Godot 2.1 beta

Creating a new asset (ie. scene) and saving it in a new folder makes the FileSystem not synchronize correctly and act weird. For example, creating a scene called Control.tscn and saving it in a new folder called "test" brings this up in the FileSystem:
![godot_2016-07-13_20-36-30](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6197645/16803618/fce4135a-4939-11e6-93c9-5ae43940a04e.png)

Re-opening the project in the editor fixes this, however.

data.title: Android: str() function is always nil
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** 2.1 alpha nightly(July 10, 2016 at 08:29) 

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When using the `str()`method in Android I will always get the error that the string I created witch `str()` is null.
On Windows everything works fine.
**Code:**

```
 func update():
        Damage = str(global.stats.get_Damage_2(0))
        Protection = str(global.stats.get_Protection())
        max_Health = str(global.stats.get_Max_Health())
        Regeneration = str(global.stats.get_Regeneration())
        damage_Mutliplier = str(global.stats.get_Damage_Multiplier())
        base_Damage = str(global.stats.get_Base_Damage())
        attackspeed_Multiplier = str(global.stats.get_Attackspeed_Multiplier())
        Knockback = str(global.stats.get_Knockback())
        Level = str(global.stats.get_Level())
        var text = "\nLevel: " + Level + "\nDamage Multiplier: " + damage_Mutliplier + "\nBase Damage: " + base_Damage + "\nDamage: " + Damage + "\nAttackspeed Multiplier: " + attackspeed_Multiplier + "\nKnockback: " + Knockback + "\nProtection: " + Protection + "\nMaximum Health: " + max_Health + "\nRegeneration: " + Regeneration
        print(text)
        #Works: set_text("text")
        set_text(text)
```

**Logcat:**

```
I/godot   (18564): 25
I/godot   (18564): 0
I/godot   (18564): 100
I/godot   (18564): 0.01
I/godot   (18564): 1
I/godot   (18564): 25
I/godot   (18564): 1
I/godot   (18564): 50
I/godot   (18564): 1
I/godot   (18564): SCRIPT ERROR: update: Invalid operands 'String' and 'Nil' in operator '+'.
I/godot   (18564):    At: res://scripts/statsLabel.gdc:33.

```

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Define a variable.
2. Make it a string using the `str()` method
3. Display the text on a label...

data.title: Live script reloading did not work
data.body:
**Operating system or device** Android Nexus 7, 6.0.1, - Godot version:2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
modify the scripts and save it will not reloaded to the running device.
And each time run on the device require uninstall and reinstall still takes a little more time compare to some other engines that can just update the modified contents. 

**Steps to reproduce:**
setup a simple func _process(delta):
and print something
run on a connected device
modify the contents in the print
still output the original contents.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Add an option to smooth camera limits when camera smoothing is enabled.
data.body:
I'm currently making a game which uses camera smoothing. When my Camera2D hits a world boundary, it stops immediately, which looks somehow disturbing.

So this option allows you to have the limits smoothed, too. It works by limiting the camera's position (instead of the transform), so it's smoothed. And yes, it's a bit hacky, so if you have improvements for that, I'll try to do my best ;-)

data.title: Fixed a crash in scenario where SSL is not available.

data.title: 2.1 beta crashes at exit on Windows 10
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1 beta 64 bits Windows 10:

The editor crashes when closed with the "stopped working" popup.
There is no error message in the console (only white text).

Step to reproduce:
Create empty project, open it, then close Godot.

Woops duplicate of #5664, two issues were posted while I was writing this one :p

data.title: Quit to Project List causes Godot to freeze
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7, Godot 2.1 beta

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Option Quit to Project List causes editor to freeze. The editor just hangs up and needs to be terminated. It throws out exception c0000005. The Project Manager window opens fine.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open/Create a project
2. Quit to project list

**Sorry for double post #5664. We post it almost at the same time. At least we know it happens also on Win 7.**

data.title: The code editor looks blurry in 2.1 compared to 2.0
data.body:
When switching to Godot 2.1 I experienced a small discomfort when using the code editor, because text looks more fuzzy than in 2.0.
This is not a big deal, but when 90% of the time your work is basically looking a text you start to notice even the slightest change.

Take a look at those screenshots taken at the exact same font size, and you should notice that in 2.1 the bars of the letters tend more to span across 2 pixels and look more blurry.
![blurry_text_2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/16787093/d6c987b8-4899-11e6-9057-dce502c7d709.png)
![blurry_text_1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/16787092/d45f64f2-4899-11e6-8931-d339aa80983f.png)

In case it's not clear, I also made a Godot project to compare them by alternating the two superimposed screenshots:
[CompareImages.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/360435/CompareImages.zip)

I'm not asking for cleartype subpixel rendering & the like, but is it possible to improve the quality like in 2.0?

data.title: Implement OS.request_attention() for OSX
data.body: Makes the dock icon bounce for 1 second.  This is only an OS X implementation for #5560, so that should be merged first.  Tested on OS X 10.11.6.

data.title: Set font size at runtime
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
All systems - all versions

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Is it possible to resize the font size at runtime for future godot versions?
I want to optimize the maximum resources used in a project / game. Therefore I want to use a maximum of 3 fonts. But I also want to use these fonts for different sizes: 12, 14, 16, 18, etc. In my opinion is nonsense to import a single font several times to use different sizes. Let me show you a simple example: having 3 fonts and using each at least 5 sizes it means 15 resources ("fnt" files). It's too much. Too much memory "eaten" by something that could be easier managed.

Suggestion:
When importing a font (ttf, etc), make a texture out of it by a size and let the game designer to choose what should be the best "pixel perfect" look like. And also let the programmer to optimize the resources he uses.

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: AtlasTexture does not repeated in sprites
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot Engine 2.0.4.1 (Ubuntu 16.04 - 64bits)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The AtlasTexture is not repeated on the sprite.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create a Sprite
- Load the AtlasTexture (or create a new one)
- Check Region on and set Region Rect (0, 0, 300, 300) (to have the "repeated effect")
- Click Edit the Texture
- Click Edit the Atlas
- Check Repeat on ImageTexture Flags.

**Image example:**

![sprite_atlastexture_bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1983402/16783300/c296a5a2-4883-11e6-8f62-8d23c073513d.png)

data.title: Signal connecting menu should let you double click on a node to connect
data.body: Currently, the node connecting dialog (where you select the name of the function, whether to make it automatically etc.) requires you to select the node, then press the `Connect` button to connect. For ease of use it'd be great to be able to connect by just double clicking on the node.

data.title: LineEdit using Center and Right align gives unexpected results when the text is wider than the control
data.body:
**Issue description**:
Using center and right align in a `LineEdit` does weird things, when the text is wider than the control. for example some text is draw outside the area of the widget and cursor don't work properly. Using left and fill align the control works normally, and all align types works properly when the text width is smaller than the total width.

![line-edit-align](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8458222/16775455/1536f084-4837-11e6-8314-65b53545c86a.png)

**Link to minimal example project**:
[line_edit_align.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/359854/line_edit_align.zip)

data.title: Added block caret to TextEdit
data.body: Added block caret to TextEdit and exposed to GDScript and properties.

data.title: Editor-connected custom signals do not work
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux (64 bit)
Godot 2.0.4.1 binary release
Godot 2.1 beta binary release

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When connecting a custom signal to a node, the connection is not actually present. It works when the `connect` function is used.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Open example project.
- Using the GUI, connect the `Ship` node's `_shoot_bullet` signal to the `BulletController` node's `on_shoot_bullet` function.
- Start the project.
- Hold Shift. A lot of lines containing `SHOOT?`, but no lines containing `SHOOT` will appear in the output window, indicating that `on_shoot_bullet` from `BulletController` is not being called.
- Open `Ship`'s script and uncomment line 8.
- Start the project.
- Hold Shift. A lot of lines containing `SHOOT` _and_ `SHOOT?` will appear, indicating that `on_shoot_bullet` from `BulletController` is being called.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
https://ptpb.pw/YfQy.zip

**Edit**: Connecting custom signals works when connecting to the root node of the scene (but still not when connected to other nodes).

data.title: Incorrect Label.get_size() value
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 64b - Godot_v2.0.4.1_stable_win64

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Label returns wrong size after setting new text.
Returned size becomes correct on the next frame.
To get the correct size one can remove / add Label to the scene.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Just try to run this code, whole project is in attachment:

```
extends CanvasLayer

var label = Label.new()

func _ready():
    label.set_text("VeryLongOne")
    print(label.get_text(), " ", label.get_size())
    add_child(label)
    print(label.get_text(), " ", label.get_size())
    label.set_text("Short")
    # wrong size
    print(label.get_text(), " ", label.get_size())
    set_process(true)

func _process(delta):
    # right size
    print(label.get_text(), " ", label.get_size())
    set_process(false)
    get_tree().quit()

```

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
Code is in attachment
[label_get_size.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/359219/label_get_size.zip)

data.title: Assetlib: unzip project in named folder
data.body:
As of 31ebac2 it's possible to select a destination to unzip the download template to, so it's great.

What's still missing is that it should IMO create a subfolder in the destination directory before unzipping the contents, especially as the dialog asking for the extract path does not propose to create a new folder itself (and complains if the given path is not a pre-existing directory).

So if I install Minilens in `/home/akien/tmp`, I end up with all the files unzipped directly in `~/tmp`, which can be messy. It should automatically append `/minilens` to the path, create the folder and unzip there.

data.title: Enable OS-specific shell hints
data.body:
While Godot is intended to be multi-platform, some OS-specific stuff is nice to have both for the editor and exposed for the games.

One example is  #3292, which can be enabled on Windows and Mac (and maybe on Linux too, at least for some DEs). On #5560 there's also a request for progress hint on the taskbar, which is on the same situation of the proposal for request attention.

There's also some stuff that is very specific to a single OS. On Windows you can extend the task bar context menu with recent files and custom tasks.

![explorer_2016-07-11_17-02-12](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5599796/16744833/46bc0ee0-4789-11e6-89dd-66b8f862754e.png)  ![2016-07-11_17-00-54](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5599796/16744805/26c15410-4789-11e6-96c7-8683654b1a80.png)

data.title: Sprites rendering bugs with high physics fps
data.body:
With physics fps set to ~200 and 60 fps lock some rendering problems appear. For example, screen flashing wtih a lot of sprites on scene.
Tested on Linux, latest Godot build from github.

data.title: Better 'or' statement
data.body:
I remember seeing this in some other language, don't know where tough. Right now, if we want to test something like this:

```
var a = 1

if (a == 1 or a == 2 or a == 3):
   #do code
```

We need to write it a lot of times.
Well, what about just writing this:

```
var a = 1

if (a == 1, 2, 3):
   #do code
```

It's specially useful when testing against variables with long names or multi-dimensional arrays:

```
if (Arr[y + 1][x] == 1 or Arr[y + 1][x] == 2 or Arr[y + 1][x] == 3):
   #do code 

if (Arr[y + 1][x] == 1, 2, 3):
   #do code 
```

So, what about having this in GDScript? Would be a nice addition.

data.title: Fix "Play custom scene" keyboard shortcut
data.body: Closes #5643.

data.title: Advanced String format with named/numbered parameters
data.body:
closes #5493

There was some new stuff to me so maybe there is better way to solve this please double check.

**UPDATE** 
Tests

```
extends Node2D

func _ready():
	test01()

var t1 = "Hello {name},\nI am {magic_teacher1} your first teacher.\n{name} can get the title {title1}"
var t1_rs = "Hello RobotGuy,\nI am Logis your first teacher.\nRobotGuy can get the title rookie"

var t2 = "Hello {0},\nI am {1} your first teacher.\n{0} can get the title {2}."
var t2_rs = "Hello RobotGuy,\nI am Logis your first teacher.\nRobotGuy can get the title rookie."

var t3 = "Hello {0},\nI am {magic_teacher1} your first teacher.\n{0} can get the title {2}."
var t3_rs = "Hello RobotGuy,\nI am Logis your first teacher.\nRobotGuy can get the title 9000.91."

var t4 = "I know your name, [name] \nI am [magic_teacher1] your first teacher.\n[name] can get the title [title1]"
var t4_rs = "I know your name, RobotGuy \nI am Logis your first teacher.\nRobotGuy can get the title rookie"

var t5 = "I know your name, [0] \nI am [1] your first teacher.\n[0] can get the title [2]"
var t5_rs = "I know your name, RobotGuy \nI am Logis your first teacher.\nRobotGuy can get the title rookie"

var t6 = "Hello {name},\nI am {0} your first teacher.\n{name} can get the title {title1}"
var t6_rs = "Hello RobotGuy,\nI am Logis your first teacher.\nRobotGuy can get the title 9000.91"

var t7 = "Hello {0},\nI am {1} your first teacher.\n{0} can get the title {2}."
var t7_rs = "Hello RobotGuy,\nI am 42 your first teacher.\nRobotGuy can get the title 9000.91."
 
var t8 = "Hello 0[. I am 1[."
var t8_rs = "Hello RobotGuy. I am Logis."

var t9 = "Hello [0. I am [1."
var t9_rs = "Hello RobotGuy. I am Logis."

var t10 = "Hello {0}. I am {9000.91}."
var t10_rs = "Hello RobotGuy. I am Logis."

var t11 = "Hello {name}. I am {magic_teacher1}."
var t11_rs = "Hello RobotGuy. I am Logis."

var t12 = "Hello name[. I am magic_teacher1[."
var t12_rs = "Hello RobotGuy. I am Logis."

var t13 = "Hello [name. I am [magic_teacher1."
var t13_rs = "Hello RobotGuy. I am Logis."

var t14 = "Hello {name}. I am {magic_teacher1}, strength {strength}."
var t14_rs = "Hello RobotGuy. I am Logis, strength 9000.91."

func test01():
	#Test01 array with dict style
	assert(t1.format([["name","RobotGuy"],["magic_teacher1","Logis"],["title1","rookie"]]) == t1_rs)

	#Test02 with array
	assert(t2.format(["RobotGuy","Logis","rookie"]) == t2_rs)
	
	#Test03 mixed array
	assert(t3.format(["RobotGuy",["magic_teacher1","Logis"],9000.91]) == t3_rs)

	#Test04 custom placeholder with dict style
	assert(t4.format([["name","RobotGuy"],["magic_teacher1","Logis"],["title1","rookie"]],"[_]") == t4_rs)
	
	#Test05 custom placeholder with array style
	assert(t5.format(["RobotGuy","Logis","rookie"],"[_]") == t5_rs)
	
	#Test06 with string,int,real as key and value
	assert(t6.format([["name","RobotGuy"],[0,"Logis"],["title1",9000.91]]) == t6_rs)

	#Test07 with string,int,real as value
	assert(t7.format(["RobotGuy",42,9000.91]) == t7_rs)

	#Test08 postfix
	assert(t8.format(["RobotGuy","Logis"],"_[") == t8_rs)
	
	#Test09 prefix
	assert(t9.format(["RobotGuy","Logis"],"[_") == t9_rs)
	
	#Test10 with dictionary
	assert(t10.format({"0":"RobotGuy",9000.91:"Logis"}) == t10_rs)
	assert(t11.format({"name":"RobotGuy","magic_teacher1":"Logis"}) == t11_rs)
	assert(t12.format({"name":"RobotGuy","magic_teacher1":"Logis"},"_[") == t12_rs)
	assert(t13.format({"name":"RobotGuy","magic_teacher1":"Logis"},"[_") == t13_rs)
	assert(t14.format({"name":"RobotGuy","magic_teacher1":"Logis","strength":9000.91}) == t14_rs)
	
	#Test error messages
	#print("1234".format(["a",[0],"b",[0,1,2]]))
	#print("1234".format(Vector2(0,0)))

```

I'm thinking about adding Dictionary.to_array() to support more use cases.

Any thoughts on the whole thing?

data.title: Added Completion box colors. Exposed show line numbers, highlight all occurrences, and updated theme.
data.body:
Added the last completion box colors  font and scroll bar).

Exposed show line numbers, highlight all occurrences to the user, through gdscript and properties.

Updated the TextEdit theme to contain the newly added colors. I didn't add `custom_bg_color` and `symbol_color` because I would have to break api compatibility to keep the styling consistent and didn't want to throw in a work around.

Lastly, updated the docs to reflect these changes.

data.title: Exclamation point ( ! ) from DroidSans looks strange in output
data.body:
Ubuntu 14.04 64-bit

```
func _ready():
    print("!")
    print("!!!")
```
